_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (CALARP)

                           AND PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM



                          ANHYDROUS AMMONIA REFRIGERATION SYSTEMS

                           CRYSTAL CREAMERY KANSAS AVENUE DAIRY



                                    Revised August 2017





                                     EXECUTIVE SUMMARY





Crystal Creamery Kansas Avenue Dairy revised this document, previously submitted in 2002, revised in December 2004,  August 2007, August 2012, and August 2017.

Crystal Creamery Kansas Avenue Dairy (hereafter referred to as Kansas Avenue Dairy) prepared a Risk Management (RM) Plan in general accordance with California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Section 2735.1, et. seq and federal regulations codified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68. The regulations are also referred to as the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program and Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP). The federal regulations are codified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 68.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Crystal Creamery prepared this RMP to satisfy regulatory requirements and to demonstrate a commitment to evaluate and improve anhydrous ammonia handling systems and practices at the facility. Crystal Creamery has incorporated state-of-the-art safety features into the ammonia refrigeration systems at the facility as part of system modifications and upgrades. Crystal Creamery will continue to improve ammonia-handling safety through the implementation of the prevention program elements of the RMP. Details of the Release Prevention and Emergency Response programs are briefly discussed below.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The Kansas Avenue Dairy (stationary source) is located at 415 Kansas Avenue in Modesto, California. The facility is classified under NAICS Code 311511

(Fluid Milk Processing). The facility is located in an area zoned for commercial and industrial use. The facility is near Highway 99, which runs approximately north and south through Modesto. Crystal Creamery is a family owned business that processes milk into fluid milk, powdered milk, and butter, and also packages fruit juices. Crystal Creamery purchased the facility in 1988. The facility has undergone significant modifications since 1988 and the majority of the ammonia refrigeration system components are less than 20 years old.



Anhydrous ammonia, CAS No. 7664-41-7, is used at the facility in two refrigeration systems ("A" and "B"). The "A" system contains approximately 19,112 pounds of ammonia and the "B" system contains approximately 20,079 pounds of ammonia. Both systems are classified as EPA Program Level 3 processes. The ammonia refrigeration systems are closed systems. Chemical reactions are not involved in these processes.  For safety, an ammonia diffusion tank (ADT) receives any blow-off from pressure relief valves (PRVs). The refrigeration systems provide cooling to the cold storage rooms, milk silos, glycol chillers, and process areas.  The cold rooms are used to store product. Some of the "A" side milk silos are jacketed with ammonia coils and store refrigerated milk and fruit juice concentrate. Glycol chillers supply cooled liquid to processing units and other equipment for refrigeration of raw materials. The "A" system provides refrigeration for the liquid products operations. The "B" system provides refrigeration for powdered processing and other operations.



General Accidental Release Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The RMP requires a review of the accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps used by the facility. The Prevention Program elements include the following: Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Mechanical Integrity, Compliance Audits, Inci

dent Investigation, Management of Change, Pre-Startup Review, Hot Work Permit Program, Contractor Safety, Employee Participation,

Lockout/Tagout Program and Line Break Program.



The Kansas Avenue Dairy has incorporated many safety features in the ammonia refrigeration systems to prevent system failures and to mitigate potential releases. The predominant safety concern with closed-loop ammonia systems is inadvertent buildup of pressure exceeding pressure ratings or capacities of equipment due to ammonia expansion. The Kansas Avenue Dairy ammonia systems are continuously monitored by automated control systems that shut down components if deviations from normal operating conditions occur. Further, the systems are equipped with pressure relief valves on pressure vessels and most, if not all, locations within the ammonia system where ammonia could become trapped. These pressure relief valves are connected by manifold to a water-filled diffusion tank. Any ammonia vapor that is unintentionally released through pressure relief valves bubbles through water that absorbs the ammonia. Other safety features at the facility include:



?    central computer monitoring and control system

?    emergency shutdown systems

?    component specific safety shutdowns that are independent of the central computer control system pressure relief valves are replaced every 5 years

?    fire alarms and sprinkler system

?    ammonia leak detection systems in the engine rooms and all process areas that contain ammonia equipment

?    an ammonia fire dump system that can be used to relieve pressure in vessels

?    a computerized preventive maintenance program

?    all ammonia piping is color coded

?    all ammonia piping, valves and components are labeled

?    operators receive regular training on ammonia system maintenance, operation and emergency response

?    SOPs for the ammonia system

?    accurate piping and instrumentation drawings for the ammonia system have been prepared and are being updated in 2017.



In addi

tion to the physical features of the ammonia refrigeration systems at the facility, Kansas Avenue Dairy has extensive administrative controls in place to maintain safe operation of the systems. Administrative controls include, but are not limited to: formal training programs for system operators and emergency responders, a hot work permit program, a lock-out/tag-out program, a contractor safety program, and a management of change program. Written standard operating procedures (SOPs) have been written for the ammonia systems at the facility and will provide a basis for site specific operator training and a ready reference for operating and trouble-shooting the systems.



Kansas Avenue Dairy is committed to maintaining the mechanical integrity of the ammonia refrigeration systems. A computerized preventive maintenance system is utilized to manage the maintenance of the refrigeration systems. Preventive maintenance at the facility includes shift, daily, weekly and periodic inspection, calibration, testing and overhaul of ammonia system equipment. The computerized system is used to track equipment performance and to create reports that are used by maintenance personnel to monitor the frequency of repairs and deviations from normal operating parameters.



Five-Year Accident History

The RMP  requires a review of the 5-year accident history at the regulated facility. The history must include "all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage."  There were no reportable releases at the facility in the last 5 years.



Emergency Response Program

In the event that an ammonia release that requires emergency response occurs at the facility, Kansas Avenue Dairy has trained refrigeration system operators for emergency response. Each operator receives 40 hours of emergency response training consiste

nt with the California Safety Training Institute (CSTI) curriculum, presented by a CSTI certified instructor. The facility has a written emergency response program that identifies the roles, responsibilities and actions of the emergency responders. Kansas Avenue Dairy will not rely on local community responders to mitigate ammonia releases at the facility. Kansas Avenue Dairy will be responsible for making initial contact with Modesto Fire Department via 9-1-1; Stanislaus County Environmental Management Department; CalOES, federal NRC, and any other agencies that need to be contacted. Kansas Avenue Dairy will rely on community responders for medical assistance and notice of public evacuation or protection in place, if necessary.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Changes to improve safety at the facility are ongoing. Mitigation measures suggested by the 2017 process hazard analysis revalidation team are being evaluated and/or implemented. Significant mitigation measures included:



?    evaluation of installing a robotic packaging system in the corrugated palletizing area to remove impact hazards to the ammonia system 



?    training regarding isolation of evaporator units.



Kansas Avenue Dairy will respond to all suggested measures to improve the safety and operations of the ammonia refrigeration system. Kansas Avenue Dairy employee participation policy provides a mechanism for all employees to provide comments and concerns to Kansas Avenue Dairy management. Management responses and support will be consistent with Kansas Avenue Dairy's commitment to safe and environmentally responsible operations.



Kansas Avenue Dairy recognizes that the RMP is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring, and improving anhydrous ammonia handling operations at its facility. As such, this document and related attachments and program elements will evolve as Kansas Avenue Dairy continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for their em

ployees and surrounding community. Kansas Avenue Dairy will submit revised information if a change occurs that is considered significant and requires resubmission under the regulations. However, minor improvements/modifications to the RMP, related attachments, and program elements will be incorporated consistent with Kansas Avenue Dairy internal review practices, and Kansas Avenue Dairy will maintain the most current versions on site. Thus, the most current version RMP, related documents, and elements maintained on site may vary slightly from the information in submittals made to EPA and other regulatory agencies
